title: Variables & Assignment
description: Learn how to store and manipulate data using variables in Python.
content: Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, you don't need to declare a variable's type explicitly - Python figures it out automatically!
keyPoints: Variables are created when you assign a value to them
Variable names should be descriptive and follow snake_case convention
Python is dynamically typed - variables can change type
Use meaningful names to make your code readable

codeExamples.title: Basic Variable Assignment
codeExamples.code:
# Creating variables
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.6
is_student = True

print(f"{name} is {age} years old")

codeExamples.title: Reassigning Variables
codeExamples.code:
# Variables can change values
score = 100
print(score)  # 100

score = 150
print(score)  # 150

# Variables can even change type!
score = "Perfect"
print(score)  # Perfect

codeExamples.title: Multiple Assignment
codeExamples.code:
# Assign multiple variables at once
x, y, z = 10, 20, 30

# Swap values easily
a, b = 5, 10
a, b = b, a  # Now a=10, b=5

title: Data Types
description: Explore Python's built-in data types: integers, floats, strings, and booleans.
content: Python has several built-in data types. The most common are: int (integers), float (decimal numbers), str (text), and bool (True/False).
keyPoints: Use type() to check a variable's type

codeExamples.title: Different Data Types
codeExamples.code:
# Integer
age = 25
print(type(age))  # <class 'int'>

# Float
pi = 3.14159
print(type(pi))  # <class 'float'>

# String
greeting = "Hello, Python!"
print(type(greeting))  # <class 'str'>

# Boolean
is_learning = True
print(type(is_learning))  # <class 'bool'>

codeExamples.title: Type Conversion
codeExamples.code:
# Converting between types
num_str = "42"
num_int = int(num_str)  # String to integer
num_float = float(num_str)  # String to float

age = 25
age_str = str(age)  # Integer to string

print(f"String: {num_str}, Int: {num_int}, Float: {num_float}")

codeExamples.title: String Operations
codeExamples.code:
# String concatenation and formatting
first_name = "John"
last_name = "Doe"

# Concatenation
full_name = first_name + " " + last_name

# F-strings (modern way)
greeting = f"Hello, {full_name}!"

# String methods
print(full_name.upper())  # JOHN DOE
print(full_name.lower())  # john doe

title: Operators
description: Master arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators in Python.
content: Operators are symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Python supports arithmetic (+, -, *, /), comparison (==, !=, <, >), and logical (and, or, not) operators.

codeExamples.title: Arithmetic Operators
codeExamples.code:
# Basic arithmetic
a = 10
b = 3

print(a + b)   # Addition: 13
print(a - b)   # Subtraction: 7
print(a * b)   # Multiplication: 30
print(a / b)   # Division: 3.333...
print(a // b)  # Floor division: 3
print(a % b)   # Modulus (remainder): 1
print(a ** b)  # Exponentiation: 1000

codeExamples.title: Comparison Operators
codeExamples.code:
# Comparing values
x = 5
y = 10

print(x == y)  # Equal to: False
print(x != y)  # Not equal to: True
print(x < y)   # Less than: True
print(x > y)   # Greater than: False
print(x <= 5)  # Less than or equal: True
print(y >= 10) # Greater than or equal: True

codeExamples.title: Logical Operators
codeExamples.code:
# Combining conditions
age = 25
has_license = True

# AND: both must be True
can_drive = age >= 18 and has_license
print(can_drive)  # True

# OR: at least one must be True
is_weekend = False
is_holiday = True
can_relax = is_weekend or is_holiday
print(can_relax)  # True

# NOT: inverts the boolean
is_working = not can_relax
print(is_working)  # False

title: Conditionals
description: Learn to make decisions in your code with if, elif, and else statements.
content: Conditional statements allow your program to make decisions and execute different code based on conditions. Python uses if, elif, and else keywords.
keyPoints: if: executes code if condition is True
elif: checks another condition if previous was False
else: executes if all previous conditions were False
You can nest conditionals inside each other

codeExamples.title: Basic If Statement
codeExamples.code:
# Simple if statement
age = 18

if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")
    print("You can vote!")

print("This always runs")

codeExamples.title: If-Elif-Else Chain
Nested Conditionals

title: Loops
description: Automate repetitive tasks using for and while loops.
content: Loops allow you to repeat code multiple times. Python has two main types: for loops (iterate over sequences) and while loops (repeat while condition is true).
keyPoints: for loop: iterate over sequences (lists, ranges, strings)
while loop: repeat while condition is True

codeExamples.title: For Loop with Range
codeExamples.code:
# Loop through numbers
for i in range(5):
    print(f"Count: {i}")
# Output: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4

# Range with start and end
for num in range(1, 6):
    print(num)
# Output: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

# Range with step
for even in range(0, 11, 2):
    print(even)
# Output: 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10

codeExamples.title: For Loop with Lists
codeExamples.code:
# Iterate over a list
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

for fruit in fruits:
    print(f"I like {fruit}")

# With index using enumerate
for index, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(f"{index + 1}. {fruit}")

codeExamples.title: While Loop
codeExamples.code:
# Repeat while condition is true
count = 0

while count < 5:
    print(f"Count is {count}")
    count += 1

# Break and continue
num = 0
while num < 10:
    num += 1
    if num == 5:
        continue  # Skip 5
    if num == 8:
        break  # Stop at 8
    print(num)

title: Functions
description: Create reusable code blocks with functions, parameters, and return values.
content: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They help organize code, avoid repetition, and make programs more modular.
keyPoints: return sends values back to caller
Functions can have default parameter values

codeExamples.title: Basic Function
codeExamples.code:
# Simple function
def greet():
    print("Hello, World!")

# Call the function
greet()  # Output: Hello, World!

# Function with parameter
def greet_person(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")

greet_person("Alice")  # Hello, Alice!

codeExamples.title: Functions with Return Values
codeExamples.code:
# Function that returns a value
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(5, 3)
print(result)  # 8

# Function with multiple returns
def calculate(a, b):
    sum_val = a + b
    diff = a - b
    product = a * b
    return sum_val, diff, product

s, d, p = calculate(10, 5)
print(f"Sum: {s}, Diff: {d}, Product: {p}")

codeExamples.title: Default Parameters
codeExamples.code:
# Function with default values
def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    return f"{greeting}, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))  # Hello, Alice!
print(greet("Bob", "Hi"))  # Hi, Bob!

# Function with docstring
def multiply(a, b):
    """
    Multiply two numbers and return the result.
    """
    return a * b

title: Lists, Tuples & Dictionaries
description: Work with Python's essential data structures for organizing collections of data.
content: Python provides powerful built-in data structures: lists (mutable sequences), tuples (immutable sequences), and dictionaries (key-value pairs).
keyPoints: Lists and dicts are mutable, tuples are immutable
Access elements by index (lists/tuples) or key (dicts)

codeExamples.title: Lists
codeExamples.code:
# Creating and modifying lists
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

# Accessing elements
print(fruits[0])  # apple
print(fruits[-1])  # cherry (last item)

# Modifying lists
fruits.append("orange")  # Add to end
fruits.insert(1, "mango")  # Insert at index
fruits.remove("banana")  # Remove by value
popped = fruits.pop()  # Remove and return last

# List slicing
print(fruits[1:3])  # Get items 1 to 2

codeExamples.title: Tuples
codeExamples.code:
# Tuples are immutable
coordinates = (10, 20)
rgb_color = (255, 128, 0)

# Accessing tuple elements
x, y = coordinates  # Unpacking
print(f"X: {x}, Y: {y}")

# Tuples are useful for fixed data
person = ("Alice", 25, "Engineer")
name, age, job = person

# Can't modify tuples (this would error):
# coordinates[0] = 15  # TypeError!

codeExamples.title: Dictionaries
codeExamples.code:
# Key-value pairs
student = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 20,
    "grade": "A",
    "courses": ["Math", "Physics"]
}

# Accessing values
print(student["name"])  # Alice
print(student.get("age"))  # 20

# Modifying dictionaries
student["age"] = 21  # Update
student["email"] = "alice@example.com"  # Add
del student["grade"]  # Delete

# Looping through dict
for key, value in student.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

title: Modules & Imports
description: Extend Python's functionality by importing and using modules.
content: Modules are Python files containing functions, classes, and variables. You can import modules to use their functionality in your code. Python has a rich standard library plus countless third-party modules.
keyPoints: Standard library has many useful modules

codeExamples.title: Importing Standard Modules
codeExamples.code:
# Import entire module
import math

print(math.pi)  # 3.14159...
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0

# Import specific functions
from random import randint, choice

print(randint(1, 10))  # Random number 1-10
print(choice(["red", "blue", "green"]))

# Import with alias
import datetime as dt

now = dt.datetime.now()
print(now)

codeExamples.title: Useful Standard Library Modules
codeExamples.code:
# os - operating system interface
import os
print(os.getcwd())  # Current directory

# json - work with JSON data
import json
data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
json_str = json.dumps(data)
print(json_str)

# collections - specialized containers
from collections import Counter
words = ["apple", "banana", "apple"]
count = Counter(words)
print(count)  # Counter({'apple': 2, 'banana': 1})

title: File Operations
description: Learn to read from and write to files in Python.
content: Python makes it easy to work with files. You can read data from files, write data to files, and manipulate file contents programmatically.
keyPoints: Always close files or use 'with' statement

codeExamples.title: Reading Files
codeExamples.code:
# Read entire file
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()
    print(content)

# Read line by line
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    for line in file:
        print(line.strip())

# Read all lines into a list
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    print(lines)

codeExamples.title: Writing Files
codeExamples.code:
# Write to file (overwrites existing)
with open('output.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write("Hello, World!\n")
    file.write("Python is awesome!")

# Append to file
with open('output.txt', 'a') as file:
    file.write("\nAppending new line")

# Write multiple lines
lines = ["Line 1\n", "Line 2\n", "Line 3\n"]
with open('output.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.writelines(lines)

codeExamples.title: Working with CSV Files
codeExamples.code:
import csv

# Write CSV
data = [
    ['Name', 'Age', 'City'],
    ['Alice', '25', 'New York'],
    ['Bob', '30', 'San Francisco']
]

with open('people.csv', 'w', newline='') as file:
    writer = csv.writer(file)
    writer.writerows(data)

# Read CSV
with open('people.csv', 'r') as file:
    reader = csv.reader(file)
    for row in reader:
        print(row)
